Star topology.

4. (c) (ii) (4 marks)

(ii) Explain two weakness of the topology in (i).

Answer

Central Point of Failure: Star topology has a central point of failure in the central node (e.g., hub or switch). If the central node fails, the entire network collapses, and communication between all connected devices is disrupted. This dependency on a single point makes the network vulnerable to complete network outages if the central node malfunctions.

Scalability Limitations: While star topology is generally scalable, very large star networks can face scalability limitations. As more devices are added to the central node, it can become a bottleneck, potentially leading to network congestion and reduced performance. The central node's capacity to handle increasing traffic and connections can limit the network's scalability in very large deployments.

4. (c) (iii) (6 marks)

(iii) Describe three types of networks based on geographic scope.

Answer

Local Area Network (LAN): A Local Area Network (LAN) is a network that connects computers and devices within a limited geographical area, such as a home, office, school, or building. LANs are typically used to share resources like printers, files, and internet access among users in close proximity. They are characterized by high-speed data transfer rates and are commonly implemented using Ethernet or Wi-Fi technologies.

Metropolitan Area Network (MAN): A Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) covers a larger geographic area than a LAN, typically spanning a city or metropolitan region. MANs connect multiple LANs together, enabling communication and resource sharing across a wider urban area. They are often used by large organizations, universities, or government agencies to connect facilities across a city. MANs utilize technologies like fiber optics and microwave links to cover metropolitan distances.

Wide Area Network (WAN): A Wide Area Network (WAN) spans a large geographical area, often covering countries, continents, or even the entire globe. WANs connect geographically dispersed networks, enabling long-distance communication and data sharing. The Internet is the largest example of a WAN, connecting billions of devices worldwide. WANs utilize technologies like leased lines, satellite links, and the internet infrastructure to facilitate global connectivity.

5. (a) (i) (2 marks)

5. (a) An organisation intends to set up voice mail services in order to support its clients countrywide.

(i) Explain the term voice mail;

Answer

Voice mail is a centralized system for managing telephone messages. It functions like an answering machine, allowing callers to leave voice messages for recipients when they are unavailable to answer the phone directly. Voice mail systems digitally record, store, and provide options for message retrieval, forwarding, and management, enhancing communication efficiency and message handling in telephone systems.

5. (a) (ii) (4 marks)

(ii) State four ways in which the organisation will benefit from such a service.

Answer

Improved Customer Service and Responsiveness: Voice mail ensures that customer calls are not missed, even when staff are busy or unavailable. Callers can leave messages detailing their needs, allowing the organization to respond promptly and efficiently, enhancing customer service and responsiveness. Timely message retrieval and follow-up improve customer satisfaction and communication quality.

24/7 Message Reception: Voice mail operates 24/7, enabling message reception outside of business hours and during non-working days. Customers can leave messages at any time, ensuring that their inquiries or requests are captured and can be addressed during the next business day. Round-the-clock message capture improves accessibility and customer convenience.

Efficient Call Handling and Reduced Missed Calls: Voice mail streamlines call handling by automatically routing unanswered calls to a message recording system. This reduces missed calls, ensures that important messages are captured, and prevents potential loss of business opportunities due to unanswered calls. Efficient call handling improves communication workflows and operational efficiency.

Enhanced Communication Flexibility and Mobility: Voice mail provides communication flexibility and supports workforce mobility. Staff can access voice messages remotely from various locations, enabling them to stay informed and respond to client needs even when they are not physically in the office. Remote message access enhances communication agility and supports flexible work arrangements.

5. (b) (4 marks)

(b) Distinguish between typical and custom software installation.

Answer

Typical Software Installation:

Typical software installation, also known as standard or default installation, is a common method where software is installed with pre-defined settings and options, suitable for most users. It usually involves minimal user input, following a straightforward wizard or setup program that automatically configures installation paths, components, and settings based on common preferences. Typical installation is designed for ease of use and quick setup for general users.

Custom Software Installation:

Custom software installation allows users to select specific components, features, and installation paths for the software. It provides flexibility for users to tailor the installation to their specific needs and preferences. Users can choose which modules to install, specify installation directories, configure advanced settings, and customize the software setup based on their requirements. Custom installation is preferred for users with specific needs or advanced technical knowledge.

Key Differences:

The main distinction is the level of user customization and control. Typical installation is automated with default settings for ease of use, while custom installation offers users the flexibility to choose specific components and settings. Typical installation is quicker and simpler, whereas custom installation is more detailed and tailored to individual user preferences or advanced configurations.

5. (c) (i) (4 marks)

(c) (i) Outline four ways in which electronic damages associated with fluids can be minimised in a laboratory.

Answer

Implement Strict No-Drinks or Food Policy: Enforce a strict "no drinks or food" policy in the laboratory to prevent accidental spills of liquids near electronic equipment. Clearly communicate and consistently enforce this policy to minimize the risk of fluid-related damages to sensitive electronics. Designated areas outside the lab should be provided for eating and drinking.

Use Spill-Proof or Sealed Containers: Utilize spill-proof or sealed containers for any fluids used in laboratory experiments or procedures conducted near electronic equipment. Ensure that containers are securely closed and designed to prevent leaks or spills, even if accidentally knocked over. Spill-resistant containers minimize the risk of fluid exposure to electronics.

Elevate Electronics and Use Protective Enclosures: Elevate electronic equipment above work surfaces to reduce the risk of fluid contact in case of spills. Use protective enclosures, such as splash guards or sealed casings, for sensitive electronics to shield them from accidental fluid splashes or spills. Elevated placement and protective enclosures create physical barriers against fluid-related damages.

Regular Inspection and Maintenance: Conduct regular inspections of electronic equipment and laboratory areas to identify and address potential fluid hazards promptly. Implement a routine maintenance schedule to check for leaks, spills, or fluid contamination near electronics. Regular inspection and maintenance help detect and mitigate fluid-related risks before they cause significant damage.

5. (ii) (6 marks)

(ii) Explain one way through which each of the following may contribute towards realisation of ergonomic standards:

I. Computer chairs;

Answer

I. Computer Chairs: Ergonomic computer chairs contribute to ergonomic standards by providing adjustable support to promote good posture and reduce musculoskeletal strain. Features like adjustable seat height, backrest, lumbar support, and armrests allow users to customize the chair to fit their body and maintain a comfortable and healthy sitting position. Ergonomic chairs reduce risks of back pain, neck strain, and other discomforts associated with prolonged sitting at a computer workstation.

5. (ii) (6 marks)

II. monitor screen;

Answer

II. Monitor Screen: Ergonomic monitor screens contribute to ergonomic standards by reducing eye strain and promoting comfortable viewing. Features like adjustable brightness, contrast, and color temperature, as well as flicker-free and low blue light emission technologies, minimize visual fatigue and eye discomfort. Proper monitor placement at eye level and adjustable tilt and swivel functions further enhance viewing comfort and reduce neck and eye strain, aligning with ergonomic principles for visual display units.

5. (ii) (6 marks)

III. work schedule.

Answer

III. Work Schedule: Ergonomic work schedules contribute to ergonomic standards by incorporating regular breaks and task variation to prevent prolonged static postures and reduce physical and mental fatigue. Scheduled breaks, rotation of tasks, and flexible work hours help minimize repetitive strain injuries, burnout, and discomfort associated with extended periods of computer work. Ergonomic work schedules promote a balanced and healthy work routine, aligning with ergonomic principles for workplace well-being.

6. (a) (2 marks)

6. (a) Outline two positive ways in which ICT has affected secretarial services in organizations.

Answer

Enhanced Efficiency and Productivity: ICT tools like word processing software, email, and scheduling applications automate and streamline secretarial tasks, increasing efficiency and productivity. Secretaries can create documents faster, manage communications more effectively, and organize schedules digitally, reducing manual effort and improving workflow speed.

Improved Communication and Information Management: ICT facilitates faster and more effective communication through email, instant messaging, and video conferencing. Digital filing systems and document management software enhance information organization, retrieval, and sharing. ICT tools improve secretarial services by enabling seamless communication and efficient information handling within organizations.

6. (b) (4 marks)

(b) A retail shop intends to install a bar code system at the point of sales terminal. Explain two benefits that the shop is likely to gain from this system.

Answer

Faster Checkout Process and Reduced Queues: Barcode systems expedite the checkout process at the point of sales terminals. Scanning barcodes is significantly faster than manual entry of product codes or prices, reducing transaction times and minimizing customer waiting lines. Faster checkout improves customer satisfaction and throughput at the sales counter.

Accurate Pricing and Inventory Management: Barcode systems ensure accurate pricing at the point of sale by automatically retrieving product prices from the database upon scanning. This eliminates pricing errors and discrepancies. Barcodes also facilitate efficient inventory management by tracking sales data, updating stock levels in real-time, and enabling accurate stock monitoring and replenishment, improving inventory control and reducing stockouts.

6. (c) (i) (6 marks)

(c) (i) Explain three sources of work related conflicts at place of work.

Answer

Task Interdependence and Workflow Disruption: Conflicts can arise from task interdependence, where employees rely on each other to complete tasks or projects. Delays, errors, or lack of cooperation from one employee can disrupt the workflow of others, leading to frustration and conflicts. Interdependencies in work processes can create friction when coordination or collaboration breaks down.

Resource Scarcity and Competition: Limited resources such as budget constraints, equipment shortages, or limited office space can be sources of work-related conflicts. Competition for scarce resources among employees or departments can lead to disputes and disagreements over resource allocation, access, or prioritization. Resource scarcity creates a competitive environment that can trigger conflicts.

Communication Barriers and Misunderstandings: Ineffective communication, lack of clarity in instructions, or cultural and linguistic differences can contribute to work-related conflicts. Misunderstandings, misinterpretations, or lack of clear communication channels can lead to errors, unmet expectations, and interpersonal friction, escalating into conflicts. Poor communication is a significant source of workplace disagreements.

6. (c) (ii) (8 marks)

(ii) Assuming that you have just been employed as a manager of a company and within your first few days in the office, you noticed that the production levels are below expectation. Explain feur factors that may indicate the existence of conflict between workers and management that could have led to decreased production.

Answer

High Employee Turnover and Absenteeism: Elevated employee turnover rates and increased absenteeism can indicate underlying conflicts between workers and management. Dissatisfaction, low morale, and unresolved conflicts may cause employees to leave the company or frequently be absent, disrupting workflow, reducing productivity, and signaling unresolved workplace issues.

Decreased Communication and Collaboration: A noticeable decline in communication and collaboration between workers and management can signify conflicts. Reduced information sharing, lack of open dialogue, and limited teamwork may indicate strained relationships and a breakdown in workplace communication. Poor communication hinders coordination, problem-solving, and productivity, reflecting underlying conflicts.

Increased Grievances and Complaints: A rise in employee grievances, complaints, or formal complaints filed against management can be a strong indicator of conflict. Frequent complaints about unfair treatment, workload issues, lack of recognition, or poor working conditions suggest unresolved conflicts and dissatisfaction among workers. Increased grievances signal systemic workplace issues impacting morale and productivity.

Resistance to Change and Lack of Cooperation: Resistance to organizational changes, new policies, or management initiatives, coupled with a lack of cooperation from workers, can point to conflicts. Employees may resist changes if they feel unheard, undervalued, or if management decisions are perceived as unfair or detrimental to their interests. Resistance and lack of cooperation hinder implementation of changes and negatively affect productivity due to underlying conflicts.

7. (a) (i) (4 marks)

7. (a) Explain the function for each of the folloy ng software:

(i) utility programs;

Answer

(i) Utility Programs: Utility programs are system software designed to perform maintenance, support, and optimization tasks for computer systems and applications. They assist in managing, configuring, and troubleshooting computer hardware, operating systems, and software. Utility programs enhance system performance, security, and efficiency by providing tools for tasks such as disk management, file management, system diagnostics, and security protection.

7. (a) (ii) (4 marks)

(ii) compilers.

Answer

(ii) Compilers: Compilers are system software tools that translate high-level programming language source code into low-level machine code that can be directly executed by a computer's processor. Compilers analyze the entire source code, perform optimizations, and generate an executable file containing machine instructions. They enable software developers to write programs in human-readable languages and convert them into machine-executable form for efficient computer processing.

7. (b) (i) (4 marks)

(b) (i) Describe each of the following input devices giving a suitable application area:

I. OCR;

Answer

I. OCR (Optical Character Recognition): OCR is an input technology that converts scanned images of text or printed documents into machine-readable text data. OCR software analyzes scanned images, identifies characters, and transforms them into digital text that can be edited, searched, and processed by computers. OCR eliminates the need for manual text entry from paper documents.

Application Area: Document Digitization and Data Entry: OCR is widely used in document digitization processes to convert paper documents into digital formats, enabling electronic archiving, indexing, and retrieval. It is also applied in automated data entry systems to extract text data from scanned forms, invoices, and receipts, streamlining data processing and reducing manual data entry efforts in various sectors like finance, administration, and document management.

7. (b) (i) (4 marks)

II. OMR.

Answer

II. OMR (Optical Mark Recognition): OMR is an input technology that detects marks made on specially designed forms, such as multiple-choice answer sheets or questionnaires. OMR scanners read filled-in bubbles or marks on paper forms and convert them into digital data. OMR is efficient for processing large volumes of structured data from standardized forms quickly and accurately.

Application Area: Surveys and Assessments: OMR is extensively used in surveys, examinations, and assessments to automate data collection and scoring from multiple-choice questionnaires and answer sheets. OMR systems rapidly process responses from large groups, accurately tally results, and generate reports for educational testing, market research surveys, and data collection applications, significantly improving efficiency and accuracy in data processing.

7. (ii) (4 marks)

(ii) Brispak, an upcoming auditing company, has adopted telecommuting as its mode of operation.

I. Define the term telecommuting.

Answer

I. Telecommuting: Telecommuting, also known as remote work or telework, is a work arrangement where employees work from a remote location, such as their home, instead of commuting to a central office or workplace. Telecommuting is enabled by ICT tools that facilitate communication, collaboration, and access to organizational resources remotely, allowing employees to perform their job duties from a distance.

7. (ii) (4 marks)

II. Outline four negative effects the company is likely to face by adopting this approach.

Answer

Reduced Team Cohesion and Collaboration: Telecommuting can reduce team cohesion and spontaneous collaboration among employees due to physical separation. Lack of face-to-face interaction may weaken team bonds, hinder informal communication, and reduce opportunities for collaborative brainstorming and problem-solving, potentially impacting team dynamics and innovation.

Communication Challenges and Misunderstandings: Remote communication in telecommuting setups can lead to challenges such as misunderstandings, misinterpretations, and delays in communication. Reliance on digital communication channels may lack the nuances of face-to-face interactions, potentially causing communication gaps, errors, and reduced clarity in work-related exchanges.

Difficulties in Monitoring and Performance Management: Monitoring employee performance and productivity in telecommuting environments can be more challenging for management. Lack of direct supervision may create difficulties in tracking work progress, ensuring accountability, and assessing employee performance effectively, requiring adjustments in management approaches and performance evaluation methods.

Isolation and Reduced Employee Engagement: Telecommuting can lead to employee isolation, reduced social interaction, and decreased engagement with the company culture. Working remotely may limit social connections with colleagues, reduce opportunities for informal workplace interactions, and potentially lead to feelings of isolation and detachment from the organizational community, affecting employee morale and engagement.

7. (c) (6 marks)

(c) With the aid of a block diagram, represent the basic elements of a computer system, indicating clearly the flow of data and control signals.

Answer

Block Diagram of Basic Elements of a Computer System:

(Unfortunately, I cannot create visual diagrams in this text-based format. However, I can describe the components and data flow for you to visualize or sketch.)

Components:

1. Input Unit: Devices like keyboard, mouse, scanner, etc., used to enter data and instructions into the computer.

2. Central Processing Unit (CPU): The brain of the computer, consisting of:

a. Control Unit (CU): Manages and coordinates all computer operations, fetches instructions, decodes them, and generates control signals.

b. Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU): Performs arithmetic calculations and logical operations on data.

c. Registers: High-speed storage locations within the CPU used for temporary data and instruction storage.

3. Memory Unit: Stores data and instructions. Includes:

a. Primary Memory (RAM): Volatile memory for temporary storage of data and instructions being actively processed.

b. Secondary Storage: Non-volatile memory (Hard Disk, SSD) for long-term data storage.

4. Output Unit: Devices like monitor, printer, speakers, etc., used to display or output processed information to the user.

Data Flow:

1. Data and instructions are entered into the computer through the Input Unit.

2. Data and instructions are stored in the Memory Unit (primarily RAM).

3. The Control Unit fetches instructions from memory and decodes them.

4. The Control Unit sends control signals to the ALU and Memory Unit to process data according to instructions.

5. The ALU performs arithmetic and logical operations on data.

6. Processed data is stored back in the Memory Unit.

7. The Output Unit receives processed data from memory and presents it to the user.

Control Signals Flow: The Control Unit sends control signals to all other units (Input, Memory, ALU, Output) to coordinate their operations. Control signals dictate data flow, operation execution, and synchronization of components.

Data Signals Flow: Data flows between Input Unit, Memory Unit, CPU (ALU and Registers), and Output Unit as per instructions and control signals. Data moves from input to memory, from memory to CPU for processing, back to memory for storage, and finally from memory to output for presentation.

8. (a) (4 marks)

8. (a) State four advantages of tailor made software over off-the-shelf software.

Answer

Precisely Meets Specific Needs: Tailor-made software is custom-built to precisely meet the unique requirements and workflows of an organization or user. It is designed to address specific business processes, functionalities, and challenges that off-the-shelf software may not adequately cover, ensuring a better fit for specific needs.

Scalability and Flexibility: Tailor-made software is inherently scalable and flexible, designed to adapt and grow with the evolving needs of the organization. It can be easily modified, upgraded, and expanded to accommodate changing business requirements, new features, or increased user demands, offering long-term adaptability.

Competitive Advantage: Tailor-made software can provide a competitive advantage by offering unique features and functionalities that are not available in generic off-the-shelf solutions. It enables organizations to differentiate themselves, implement innovative solutions, and gain a strategic edge by leveraging custom-built software tailored to their specific business strategies.

Integration with Existing Systems: Tailor-made software can be seamlessly integrated with an organization's existing IT infrastructure, legacy systems, and databases. Custom development allows for specific interfaces and compatibility to be built in, ensuring smooth data flow, system interoperability, and streamlined workflows across integrated systems, avoiding integration challenges often encountered with off-the-shelf software.

8. (b) (4 marks)

(b) Distinguish between integrated software and software suites.

Answer

Integrated Software:

Integrated software refers to a single application that combines multiple functionalities and tools from different software categories into one unified program. It is designed as a single, cohesive unit where various modules or components are tightly integrated and share data seamlessly within the application. Integrated software aims to provide a comprehensive solution for diverse tasks within a single application environment.

Software Suites:

Software suites are collections of separate, standalone software applications that are bundled together and sold as a package. Each application within a software suite is a distinct program designed for a specific purpose (e.g., word processing, spreadsheet, presentation). While applications in a suite are designed to work together and may offer some level of integration, they remain separate programs that are launched and operated independently.

Key Differences:

The core difference lies in the level of integration and structure. Integrated software is a single application with combined functionalities, whereas software suites are bundles of separate applications. Integrated software offers seamless data sharing within one program, while suites consist of distinct programs that may have interoperability but are not inherently unified as a single application. Integrated software is a singular, comprehensive tool, while software suites are collections of individual applications bundled for convenience and sometimes cost-effectiveness.

8. (c) (4 marks)

(c) Outline four differences between primary and secondary storage in a computer system.

Answer

Volatility: Primary storage (RAM) is volatile memory, meaning it loses stored data when power is turned off. Secondary storage (Hard Disk, SSD) is non-volatile, retaining data even when power is removed. Volatility is a key distinction in how they retain data; primary storage is temporary, while secondary storage is permanent.

Access Speed: Primary storage (RAM) offers much faster data access speeds compared to secondary storage. RAM allows for rapid reading and writing of data, enabling quick CPU access for processing. Secondary storage devices have slower access times due to mechanical components (HDDs) or interface limitations, resulting in slower data retrieval and storage operations.

Cost per Gigabyte: Primary storage (RAM) is significantly more expensive per gigabyte compared to secondary storage. RAM is designed for high-speed performance, which increases its manufacturing cost. Secondary storage, especially HDDs, offers much lower cost per gigabyte, making it more economical for storing large volumes of data.

Purpose and Usage: Primary storage (RAM) is used for temporary storage of data and instructions that the CPU is actively processing. It serves as the main working memory of the computer. Secondary storage is used for long-term, persistent storage of data, applications, and files, even when the computer is powered off. Primary storage is for active processing, while secondary storage is for data archiving and long-term retention.

8. (d) (i) (2 marks)

(d) A school bought refurbished computers which had software already installed. The computer technician decided to format the computer hard disks and reinstall the software in all the computers.

(i) Outline two reasons that could be have prompted the technician to take this action.

Answer

Security Concerns and Malware Removal: Formatting hard disks and reinstalling software can be prompted by security concerns, such as potential malware or viruses present on the refurbished computers from previous users. Formatting ensures complete data erasure and removal of any potentially harmful software, providing a clean and secure system for the school's use.

Standardization and Clean Installation: The technician may format hard disks to standardize the software environment across all computers and ensure a clean installation of necessary software. Refurbished computers may have varied software configurations from previous use. Formatting and reinstalling allows for a uniform and controlled software setup, optimized for the school's specific educational needs and software requirements.

8. (d) (ii) (4 marks)

(ii) Describe the stages that the technician should follow in order to install the operating system successfully. Assume the hard disks had very large disk spaces.

Answer

Boot from Installation Media: The technician should first boot the computer from the operating system installation media, such as a DVD or USB drive. This typically involves changing the boot order in the BIOS/UEFI settings to prioritize booting from the installation media. Booting from the installation media initiates the OS setup process.

Partition and Format Hard Disk: During OS installation, the technician should partition and format the hard disk. With large disk spaces, creating multiple partitions (e.g., for OS, applications, data) may be advisable for better organization. The partition where the OS will be installed needs to be formatted with a compatible file system (e.g., NTFS for Windows) to prepare it for OS files.

Install Operating System Files: The OS installation process will copy necessary operating system files to the selected hard disk partition. This stage involves extracting installation files, configuring system settings, and setting up core OS components. The technician should follow on-screen prompts to provide required information like language, time zone, and user account details.

Configure System and Install Drivers: After OS file installation, the technician should configure system settings, such as network configurations, device settings, and user preferences. Install necessary hardware drivers for devices like graphics cards, network adapters, and peripherals to ensure proper hardware functionality and compatibility with the newly installed operating system.

8. (d) (iii) (2 marks)

(iii) During the installation of an operating system in one of the computers, the technician observed the following error message;

"Searching for Boot Record from CDROM..OK

Press any key to boot from CD..... Error loading operating system_"

Explain two possible causes of this error.

Answer

Corrupted or Incompatible Installation Media: The error "Error loading operating system" can be caused by corrupted or incompatible OS installation media (CD/DVD or USB drive). Damaged installation media may lack necessary boot files or have corrupted OS installation files, leading to failure in loading the operating system during setup.

Incorrect Boot Order or BIOS Settings: Incorrect boot order settings in BIOS/UEFI or improper configuration can cause the error. If the computer is not correctly set to boot from the installation media (CD/DVD or USB), or if BIOS settings are misconfigured, the system may fail to load the OS installation files, resulting in the "Error loading operating system" message.
